image.altText: Apartments being built.

props.synopsis: A new model of housing development is being touted as a solution to the housing crisis. But is it a game changer or more of the same for renters across New South Wales?

title.children: Build-to-rent housing is gaining momentum, so will it help ease the rental crisis?

image.altText: a composite picture of a rural landscape overlaid with a map of the NSW coast, with a inset picture of a 10-storey high house

props.synopsis: With home gym, rooftop spa, indoor swimming pool and whole-floor tennis court, this 10-storey, single family residence would look at home among the apartment towers of the Gold Coast.

title.children: Is this Australia's tallest house? This 10-storey rural monolith comes with a suspended observation deck

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jumper looks at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A speech pathologist says Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne was running controversial practices as late as February last year.

title.children: Anica has seen a lot in her job, but this experience left her 'physically shaking'

image.altText: Paul Burnham wearing Australia jacket

props.synopsis: The distinctive jacket worn by Bob Hawke when he celebrated Australia's upset win of the America's Cup in 1983 was, in fact, designed by a 23-year-old architecture student to parody nationalistic fervour.

title.children: Designer reveals the irony stitched into 'silly' Australia jacket made famous by Bob Hawke in 1983

image.altText: White woman with curled blonde hair wears blue chrome armor and red cape, while blonde man wears the same in background.

props.synopsis: The screen industry funding cut, affecting high-end television and blockbuster film productions, was confirmed in the state budget last week.

title.children: NSW government reinstates $60m funding to film and television industry a week after budget cut

image.altText: Daniel Andrews speaks to media during a press conference at Ambulance Victoria Training Centre.

props.synopsis: Victorian Labor MPs will meet at midday to discuss a successor to Premier Daniel Andrews, following his shock resignation on Tuesday.

title.children: Victorian Labor caucus looks to Andrews's successor after shock resignation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More from state political reporter Bridget Rollason, who's down at Parliament House: Arriving at parliament, the Victorian treasurer says the outcome of the new leader is "entirely in the hands of the caucus" but hasn't ruled out a tilt at deputy. "People have been writing me off for many years now," Mr Pallas says. "I haven't made a decision about my future other than I want to serve Labor for as long as I possibly can."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tim Pallas won't rule out running for deputy leadership

children.content: More from state political reporter Bridget Rollason, who's down at Parliament House:
Arriving at parliament, the Victorian treasurer says the outcome of the new leader is "entirely in the hands of the caucus" but hasn't ruled out a tilt at deputy.

props.alt: Tim Pallas speaks to journalists outside parliament.

children.content: Treasurer Tim Pallas says he wants to continue to serve Labor.
(ABC News: Bridget Rollason)
"People have been writing me off for many years now," Mr Pallas says.
"I haven't made a decision about my future other than I want to serve Labor for as long as I possibly can."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A seasoned politician, Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan smiles as she rebuffs multiple questions about her likely elevation to the top job. Three times she tells journalists she's respecting colleagues by letting the caucus process "run its course" before heading indoors.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: An upbeat Jacinta Allan arrives at parliament

children.content: A seasoned politician, Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan smiles as she rebuffs multiple questions about her likely elevation to the top job.
Three times she tells journalists she's respecting colleagues by letting the caucus process "run its course" before heading indoors.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In announcing his resignation, Daniel Andrews said the Labor caucus would meet at midday today to choose a successor, and he'd be gone by 5pm. But the Victorian Labor Party's rules actually state that when choosing a new leader, nominations are open for three days. They also state that someone who's in the running for the top job can't be the interim leader during that time. But state political reporter Bridget Rollason says she's hearing some Labor MPs are keen to override those rules today, so they can lock in a leader with a minimum of drama. "We reckon the caucus can vote to overrule the party rules if there is only one nomination tomorrow to get it done," one senior Labor figure told her. So in short, we don't know for sure — nominations may run for a few days, or we could see a new Labor leader before dinner.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will we have a new Labor leader today or not?

children.content: In announcing his resignation, Daniel Andrews said the Labor caucus would meet at
midday today
to choose a successor, and he'd be gone by
5pm
But the Victorian Labor Party's rules actually state that when choosing a new leader,
nominations are open for three days
They also state that someone who's in the running for the top job can't be the interim leader during that time.
But state political reporter Bridget Rollason says she's hearing
some Labor MPs are keen to override those rules today, so they can lock in a leader with a minimum of drama
"We reckon the caucus can vote to overrule the party rules if there is only one nomination tomorrow to get it done," one senior Labor figure told her.
So in short, we don't know for sure — nominations may run for a few days, or we could see a new Labor leader before dinner.

image.altText: Daniel Andrews.

props.synopsis: Victoria's longest-serving – and Australia's highest-paid — premier is just hours from stepping down after more than 3,200 days leading the state. Here are the hits and misses of Daniel Andrews.

title.children: Daniel Andrews steps down as an undefeated leader. What were his legacies?

image.altText: an aerial shot of three beachfront highrise towers on the Gold Coast

props.synopsis: The Jewel's eye-catching towers are the sparkling gem in the Surfers Paradise skyline, but three years after they were built, hundreds of luxury apartments remain empty and most are not up for sale.

title.children: The curious case of the Jewel and the Gold Coast's near-empty $1.5b towers

image.altText: school children playing handball in red and yellow uniforms

props.synopsis: Across ages, between schools, towns and states, there are plenty of varieties of the rules. So how is it possible to stage an inter-school handball championship where everyone is on the same page?

title.children: This school managed to navigate more than 200 handball rules to have the 'Best. Day. Ever'

image.altText: Humorous sign with writing on it advertising a pub.

props.synopsis: The century-old Urandangi Hotel is being demolished, leaving the community with nowhere to buy meals, fuel or groceries for hundreds of kilometres.

title.children: Outback town left with 'nothing' after record floods force pub's demolition

image.altText: Australia's parliament house on a clear sunny day with tick and cross checkboxes illustrated over the top.

props.synopsis: Despite being on the cusp of early voting for the Voice to Parliament referendum, many still have questions about the proposal, one of them being; why can't it just be legislated?

title.children: You Ask We Answer: Why has the government opted for a referendum on the Voice to Parliament rather than legislation?

image.altText: Silhouettes of a four people with disability against a teal background

props.synopsis: The disability royal commission is wrapping up after four-and-a-half years. Here's how we got here and what comes next.

title.children: The disability royal commission is set to report this week. Here's a recap of the past four years

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: A judge rules that Donald Trump committed fraud for years while building the real estate empire that catapulted him to fame and the White House.

title.children: Donald Trump defrauded banks for years, New York civil case rules

image.altText: A footballer looks dejected after a loss.

props.synopsis: Insult is added to injury for the struggling Wallabies, as Argentina jumps the Australians in the rugby world rankings.

title.children: Wallabies hit historic low in world rankings as South Americans leapfrog struggling Australians

image.altText: acrobats in silhouette with some performers in the air with orange background

props.synopsis: Contemporary circus in Australia has been left reeling as Swinburne University pauses the 2024 intake for NICA's circus arts degree.

title.children: 'Why would we trash a national treasure?' Future of Australia's only tertiary circus school in doubt

image.altText: A man with glasses and a navy blue suit and tie stands behind a lecturn at a business conference

props.synopsis: The Australian Shareholders' Association has joined the growing chorus of calls demanding Qantas's chairman Richard Goyder resign from his position, and has placed the rest of the airline's board on notice after weeks of scandals.

title.children: Qantas shareholders demand Richard Goyder quit as chairman as 'more things come to light' about management decisions

image.altText: A fire at an industrial site at night.

props.synopsis: Firefighting crews worked through the night to contain the blaze. People in the area were urged to stay indoors to protect themselves from the hazardous smoke.

title.children: Tesla battery on fire at major Queensland renewable energy storage site

image.altText: Anthony Rota delivers a speech from the speaker's chair in Canada's parliament.

props.synopsis: The speaker of Canada's House of Commons resigns after inviting a man who fought for a Nazi military unit during World War II to parliament to attend a speech by Ukraine's president.

title.children: Canada's speaker quits after man who fought for Nazis received standing ovation in parliament

image.altText: An older gentlalnd with grey hair and glasses stands in front of dozens of freshly ironed and covered clohtes on coathangers

props.synopsis: After running his family's Tamworth-based dry cleaners for 61 years, Ross says there is one stain he certainly won't miss.

title.children: Dry cleaning family to hang up the iron after 82 years of 'mud, blood and beer'

image.altText: A man with a weathered face stands on a concrete pass looking over a creek on a sunny green acre lined with trees.

props.synopsis: Despite having little to do with the Voice, the blowing up of ancient rock shelters and a bungled attempt to preserve Aboriginal heritage are the issues shaping the referendum debate in WA.

title.children: How this banal concrete driveway became emblematic of WA's unique debate about the Voice

image.altText: A woman and man in hard hats and high vis vests

props.synopsis: Deputy premier Jacinta Allan and public transport minister Ben Carroll are said to be the leading candidates for the vacated premier job.

title.children: The fight to be Victoria's next premier is likely down to just two candidates

image.altText: Activists hold up placards about climate justice

props.synopsis: Environmental activists in the Philippines say they face killings, disappearances and being labelled a communist or terrorist as they are targeted by state-backed and private forces.

title.children: This is the deadliest country in Asia to defend the environment

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

props.synopsis: A fall on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower, while the August monthly CPI figure is tipped to edge higher. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to drop ahead of August CPI figure, Wall Street sinks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Telstra chief Ziggy Switkowski has unveiled a review of PwC in the wake of the tax leaks scandal, but it's unlikely this is the end of an intense probe of its business and the way other consulting firms manage conflicts of interest. Read this analysis by Nassim Khadem .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC review doesn't stop conflicts of interest

featuredLink.title: PwC review won't stop firms getting paid to audit companies while simultaneously helping them minimise tax

children.content: Former Telstra chief Ziggy Switkowski has unveiled a review of PwC in the wake of the tax leaks scandal,
but
it's unlikely this is the end of an intense probe of its business and the way other consulting firms manage conflicts of interest.
Read this analysis by
Nassim Khadem

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Senate inquiry into management and assurance of integrity by consulting services is up today. The Department of Finance will be questioned at 9am AEST, followed by the appearance of KPMG at 11:30am AEST. We will bring you live updates as it happens.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: KPMG to front Senate inquiry

children.content: The Senate inquiry into management and assurance of integrity by consulting services is up today.
The Department of Finance will be questioned at 9am AEST, followed by the appearance of KPMG at 11:30am AEST.
We will bring you live updates as it happens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB expects August CPI Indicator to rise to an annual pace of 5.2 per cent from July’s 4.9 per cent, in line with the consensus. It thinks a surge in fuel prices (+8.5pc) is a main driver. The bank also predicts prices of fruit and vegetables to slide further in August following strong winter growing conditions. "More broadly, food inflation has slowed from nearly 10 per cent to 5.6 per cent year on year in July and [we] expect it to cool further to below 4 per cent year on year in August," NAB said. The bank added that the RBA would lift rates again in November. "We expect robust price increases across components including meals/takeaway, hairdressing and other household and recreation services, to contrast against cooling grocery and durable goods inflation," NAB said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: August Monthly CPI to be back above 5pc: NAB

children.content: NAB expects
August CPI Indicator to rise to an annual pace of 5.2 per cent from July’s 4.9 per cent, in line with the consensus.
It thinks a surge in fuel prices (+8.5pc) is a main driver.
The bank also predicts prices of fruit and vegetables to slide further in August following strong winter growing conditions.
"More broadly, food inflation has slowed from nearly 10 per cent to 5.6 per cent year on year in July and [we] expect it to cool further to below 4 per cent year on year in August," NAB said.
The bank added that
the RBA would lift rates again in November

"We expect robust price increases across components including meals/takeaway, hairdressing and other household and recreation services, to contrast against cooling grocery and durable goods inflation," NAB said.

image.altText: Man wearing a suit and black jacket standing next to a wall.

props.synopsis: Victoria is in the grip of a heroin addiction problem. Experts say too few people are getting access to the treatment they need and that needs to change before fentanyl becomes a bigger issue in Australia.

title.children: Fentanyl has wreaked havoc in the United States. These experts worry Victoria could be next

image.altText: An Australian Kelpie and a woman wearing a red top.

props.synopsis: Violet the dog was vomiting, urinating, and struggling to breathe while suffering a violent high from eating marijuana that had been left at a Brisbane park.

title.children: Violet the kelpie nearly died from a violent high after eating marijuana at a dog park

image.altText: Handcuffed prisoner being led in corridor by warden.

props.synopsis: Child sexual abuse at Tasmania's only youth detention facility "remains a live and current risk" and not a historical problem, a two-year inquiry finds. The state premier says he would close it now if he could but there are no other options for housing child inmates.

title.children: Sexual abuse of children in a notorious youth prison a 'current risk', damning report finds

image.altText: An NRL player stand allow, yelling wiht excitement, puffing his chest.

props.synopsis: Penrith winger Brian To'o has become one of the best big-game players in rugby league. The question is whether it can land the Panthers flyer a slice of rugby league history in Sunday's grand final, writes Nick Campton.

title.children: Brian To'o is a finals beast but even he might find creating history in the NRL Grand Final a bridge too far

image.altText: Side by side photos of business logos for accounting firms Deloitte, PwC, KPMG and EY

props.synopsis: Former Telstra chief Ziggy Switkowski has unveiled a review of PwC in the wake of the tax leaks scandal, but it's unlikely this is the end of an intense probe of its business and the way other consulting firms manage conflicts of interest, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: PwC review won't stop firms getting paid to audit companies while simultaneously helping them minimise tax

image.altText: man smiling without a shirt on

props.synopsis: A jury hears a frantic emergency call made by a woman trying to save the life of a man allegedly stabbed to death by Raymond Allen, 41, on the New South Wales South Coast.

title.children: Jury hears neighbour's desperate triple-0 call following alleged caravan park murder

image.altText: Outside of PWC building

props.synopsis: Embattled consulting giant PwC will today announce a major overhaul of governance, culture and accountability when it releases a long-awaited independent review into a tax leak scandal that has badly damaged the firm's reputation.

title.children: PwC to announce major overhaul alongside findings of probe of tax leak scandal

image.altText: Penguins on a iceberg.

props.synopsis: Sea ice that packs the ocean around Antarctica hit record low levels this winter, adding to scientists' fears the impact of climate change at the southern pole is ramping up.

title.children: Antarctic winter sea ice hits 'extreme' record low
